reviews.review_msg: Chariandy was genuinely excited by the topics and expressed compassion for students. Thought-provoking books, even if I didn't love them all. He let students talk too much then sometimes end would feel rushed, but he posted the slides after. The essay prompt was harder to grasp but was on topic with the course, and he was always open to questions.

Prof Chariandy is so nice and makes everyone feel like their opinions and ideas are valued. His lectures can sometimes be boring, but it's English so you can't blame him. I suggest attending class (I did not and found it harder to study for final) as he bases 1/3 of the final on lecture notes and class discussion.

Reading list had fairly boring books; nothing really stood out. Her lectures were also boring. Most people were not engaged, opting instead to go on Facebook or just straight fall asleep. Attendance wasn't really mandatory until she noticed how few people showed up, and then she started making us write things during lecture and hand them in.

For online, you will likely not interact with Prof. Colligan. Most of your interaction will be with your TA, so experiences may vary. That being said, New Yorker stories is full of short stories you will enjoy. This is likely the first english class I have enjoyed the readings in. Expect 1-2 hours of reading a week, and 2-3 essays for the course.

The worst teacher I've ever seen. She does not really use too much materials to explain but just follows her mind. I got a lower mark in my midterm1 and the class average was not high which was around C no higher than B-. She forces students to answer her question otherwise she will get mad at students and start to judge students.

Class attendance is essentially a waste of time, the lectures aren't important or related to what you are graded on. Class attendance dropped to half the original number, a week into the semester. Basically people only attend class if they're around, bored or have nothing better to do. Actual course is simple, books are boring though.
